Utterance: <sync>
Hi again! How have you been since our last session?
Um, I've been pretty good, just busy with work and painting.
That’s great to hear! Did you have any thoughts about what we discussed last time?
Yeah, I’ve been thinking about how I handle my emotions and my art.
That’s a good reflection. Have you noticed any changes in your emotional responses?
I think I’ve been more aware of when I feel overwhelmed.
That’s a positive step! What do you do when you start to feel overwhelmed?
I try to take a break and paint or go for a walk. It helps clear my mind.
Excellent coping strategies! Have you found any specific techniques in painting that help you express those emotions?
Yeah, I’ve been experimenting with colors more. Like, when I’m anxious, I use darker colors, and when I’m happy, I go for brighter ones.
That’s a wonderful way to channel your emotions! Have you had a chance to paint anything new lately?
I actually started a new piece last week. It’s abstract, with lots of blues and greens.
Sounds beautiful! What inspired that piece?
I was feeling a bit nostalgic, thinking about my childhood and the ocean.
Nostalgia can be a powerful emotion. How did that feeling translate into your art?
I think it made me want to capture the calmness of the ocean and the joy of those memories.
That’s a lovely intention. Do you feel that painting helps you process those memories?
Definitely, it’s like therapy for me.
I’m glad to hear that. Are there any memories that you find more challenging to express?
Yeah, sometimes the tougher memories, like the ones with violence, are hard to put on canvas.
That’s understandable. Would you like to explore those memories a bit more today?
I guess so. I mean, it’s tough, but I think it could be helpful.
Absolutely, take your time. Can you share one of those memories?
Well, there was this time I saw someone get jumped. I was just a kid, and it scared me.
That sounds traumatic. How did you feel during that experience?
I felt helpless and scared. I didn’t know what to do.
It’s natural to feel that way in such a situation. Do those feelings come back to you sometimes?
Yeah, sometimes I get anxious in crowded places.
That makes sense. Have you noticed any specific triggers that lead to that anxiety?
Loud noises or people getting too close.
Have you tried any grounding techniques when you feel that way?
I’ve tried deep breathing, but it doesn’t always work.
That’s a good start. Would you like to explore some other techniques together?
Sure, that could be helpful.
One technique is the 5-4-3-2-1 grounding exercise. Would you like to try it?
Yeah, what do I need to do?
First, identify five things you can see around you.
Okay, I see my paintbrush, a canvas, my phone, a plant, and a window.
Great! Now, can you name four things you can touch?
Um, the paintbrush, the canvas, my chair, and my desk.
Perfect! Now, how about three things you can hear?
I hear the clock ticking, some cars outside, and my breathing.
Good job! Next, can you identify two things you can smell?
I can smell the paint and a bit of the coffee from earlier.
Awesome! Finally, what’s one thing you can taste?
I can taste the mint from my gum.
How do you feel after doing that exercise?
I feel a bit more grounded, actually.
That’s wonderful! You can use this exercise whenever you start feeling anxious.
I’ll definitely try that.
Is there anything else you’d like to explore today?
I guess I’m still thinking about my family.
Sure! What’s on your mind regarding your family?
I just wonder if I’m doing enough to support them.
It’s great that you care about them. In what ways do you currently support them?
I help out when I can, like with chores and stuff.
That’s important. Have you communicated with them about how they feel you’re doing?
Not really. I guess I’m afraid of what they might say.
It’s natural to have that fear. Would you like to practice how you might approach that conversation?
Yeah, that could help.
Okay, let’s role-play. You can start the conversation.
Um, hey family, I just wanted to check in and see how you feel about my support.
That’s a good start! Now, how do you think they might respond?
They might say I’m doing fine, but I’m worried they’ll say I’m not enough.
It’s okay to have those worries. Remember, their feedback can help you grow.
Yeah, I see that.
Do you feel ready to have that conversation?
I think so.
That’s great! Let’s set that as a goal for the week.
Sounds good!
Before we wrap up, is there anything else you want to discuss?
No, I think that’s it for today.
Okay, thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings. I look forward to hearing how your conversation with your family goes next time!
Yeah, me too. Thanks!
You’re welcome. Take care!
Bye!
Bye!
